verses.text: Then I looked, and above the expanse that was over the heads of the cherubim, there appeared over them something like a sapphire stone, looking like a throne.
verses.comment: This vision repeats language from Ezekiel 1, emphasizing the majesty and transcendence of God, sitting enthroned over the cherubim. The throne imagery points ahead to Christ's kingship (see John 18:36; Hebrews 1:8).

verses.text: And he spoke to the man clothed in linen, and said, 'Go in between the whirling wheels, beneath the cherubim, and fill your hands with burning coals from between the cherubim, and scatter them over the city.' And he went in before my eyes.
verses.comment: The action of scattering coals symbolizes judgment and purification. The man in linen often represents angelic service or even Christ as intercessor (cf. Dan. 10:5; Heb. 7:25).

verses.text: Now the cherubim were standing on the south side of the temple when the man went in, and the cloud filled the inner court.
verses.comment: The cloud is consistently a sign of the divine presence (see Ex. 40:34; 1 Kings 8:10). In the New Testament, the cloud often signals God's glory in Christ (Mark 9:7).

verses.text: And the glory of the LORD went up from the cherub to the threshold of the temple, and the temple was filled with the cloud, and the court was filled with the brightness of the LORD's glory.
verses.comment: The glory departing is a sign of impending judgment but also foreshadows restoration. The brightness recalls the divine light seen in Christ's transfiguration (Luke 9:29, 32).

verses.text: And the sound of the wings of the cherubim was heard as far as the outer court, like the voice of God Almighty when He speaks.
verses.comment: God's voice is compared to thunder throughout Scripture (Ps. 29:3–9; John 12:28–29). This scene conveys awe and power, anticipating the theophany of Christ in Revelation (Rev. 1:15).

verses.text: And when He commanded the man clothed in linen, 'Take fire from between the wheels, from between the cherubim,' he went in and stood beside a wheel.
verses.comment: The wheels symbolize the mysterious mobility and sovereignty of God's presence. Fire is often a sign both of judgment and purification (Mal. 3:2–3).

verses.text: And a cherub stretched out his hand from between the cherubim to the fire that was between them. He took some of the fire and put it into the hands of the man clothed in linen, who took it and went out.
verses.comment: The cherubim act at God's command, demonstrating the cooperation of created beings with God's purpose—an early type of angelic ministry and mediation.

verses.text: And there appeared in the cherubim the form of a human hand under their wings.
verses.comment: The human hand imagery recalls the union of divine and human attributes, a theme fulfilled in Christ who unites divinity and humanity (see Phil. 2:6–8).

verses.text: When I looked, there were four wheels beside the cherubim, one wheel beside each cherub, and the wheels appeared as if sparkling like beryl stone.
verses.comment: The wheels’ sparkling quality points toward the preciousness and perfection of God's design. Beryl is a gemstone associated with sacredness (cf. Rev. 21:20).

verses.text: As for their appearance, the four had the same likeness, as if a wheel were within a wheel.
verses.comment: The complex structure represents the mysterious nature of God’s guidance. Early interpreters saw in this a symbol of divine omnipresence and providence.

verses.text: When they moved, they went in any of their four directions without turning as they moved, but followed the direction the head was facing. They did not turn as they went, but in whatever way the head faced, they followed.
verses.comment: This describes the perfect obedience of the spiritual beings to God’s will. Christian tradition often draws an analogy to the faithful following of Christ, who is the true head (Eph. 5:23).

verses.text: Their entire bodies—their flesh, their backs, their hands, their wings, and the wheels—were full of eyes all around, the wheels they each had.
verses.comment: Eyes symbolize knowledge and vigilance, associated in Christian liturgy with the all-seeing presence of God and the angelic choirs described in Revelation.

verses.text: As for the wheels, they were called 'whirling wheels' in my hearing.
verses.comment: The ‘whirling’ aspect suggests the restless energy and vitality of God’s presence throughout creation.

verses.text: Each cherub had four faces. The first was the face of a cherub, the second was the face of a man, the third was the face of a lion, and the fourth was the face of an eagle.
verses.comment: The four faces express the fullness of creation—humanity, wild animals, domestic animals, and birds—serving God. Early Christian tradition associated these with the four evangelists (Irenaeus, Augustine).

verses.text: And the cherubim rose up. These were the living creatures I saw by the River Chebar.
verses.comment: Ezekiel confirms the connection to his first vision, reinforcing the unity and consistency of divine revelation across time.

verses.text: And when the cherubim moved, the wheels moved beside them. And when the cherubim lifted up their wings to rise from the earth, the wheels did not turn from beside them.
verses.comment: The inseparable movement stresses the harmony in God's executing will. This has been interpreted spiritually as the harmony of the Church with the guidance of the Holy Spirit (Acts 15:28).

verses.text: When they stood still, the wheels stood still. When they rose up, the wheels rose up with them, for the spirit of the living creatures was in the wheels.
verses.comment: Again, the total unity of movement and purpose is emphasized. Such imagery prefigures the unity of Christ’s body, where the Spirit works through all members (1 Cor. 12:12).

verses.text: Then the glory of conflict moved out from above the threshold of the temple and stood over the cherubim.
verses.comment: The movement of God's glory prefigures the withdrawal of God’s presence as judgment increases—a significant moment of loss, yet also hope for future restoration (see John 2:19).

verses.text: And the cherubim lifted their wings and rose up from the earth before my eyes as they went out, with the wheels beside them. They stood at the entrance of the east gate of the LORD's house, and the glory of the God of Israel was over them.
verses.comment: The east gate will be significant for the return of God’s glory (Ezekiel 43). Early Christians connected the coming and going of the ‘glory’ with the presence and return of Christ (Acts 1:11).

verses.text: These were the living creatures that I saw under the God of Israel by the River Chebar, and I realized that they were cherubim.
verses.comment: Ezekiel clarifies the identity of the beings he first saw, confirming the unity of God’s heavenly council (Heb. 12:22).

verses.text: Each had four faces, each had four wings, and under their wings was something like the form of human hands.
verses.comment: The human hands under the wings reinforce the theme that God works through visible and invisible means. This has been spiritually interpreted as God using both heavenly and earthly ministers.

verses.text: As for the likeness of their faces, they were the same faces whose appearance I had seen by the River Chebar. Each went straight ahead.
verses.comment: Their unwavering movement and unchanging faces signify faithfulness in service. Christians are called to imitate this steadfast commitment in following Christ (Heb. 12:2).
